docs.lead_paragraph: Mental health care advocates long viewed South Florida State Psychiatric Hospital here as a dumping ground, a place where patients were treated poorly, languished for years and died mysteriously. But South Florida State, only a few years ago threatened with closing as the way to solve its problems, is now at the heart of an experiment. Experts say it is the first state mental hospital in the nation to be turned over completely to a private company that hopes to operate it at a profit.

headline.main: Experiment of Privatized Mental Hospital Shows Benefits

docs.abstract: Mental health care experts point to South Florida State Psychiatric Hospital in Pembroke Pines as first state mental hospital in nation to be turned over completely to private company that hopes to operate it at profit; local advocates for mentally ill now say conditions at hospital have improved since Atlantic Shores Healthcare, subsidiary of Wackenhut Corrections Corp, won contract to run it; note that patients, rather than staying indefinitely, are put into treatment programs intended to get them out; Wackenhut is paid $32 million a year to operate hospital, its budget when it was run by state; company's profit will come from cost savings; some experts fear Wackenhut is spending more at South Florida State now than it will in future in hope of establishing track record to help market itself to other states; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The government's coordinator for the year 2000 conversion said today that his concerns about the readiness of hospitals, prisons and emergency service organizations had been allayed, and Pentagon officials struck a carefully calibrated tone of caution mixed with confidence that they could deal with any terrorist attacks around the New Year's holiday. They spoke as the government entered the last five days of preparations for possible computer malfunctions and terrorist threats. Government officials have started to show off the White House command center for dealing with threats, which keeps tabs on things like the amount of cash withdrawn from automated teller machines and suspicious activities along the borders of the United States.

Pataki and the leaders of the State Legislature basked in the spotlight after agreeing this month on an ambitious effort to double New York State's cigarette tax as part of a plan to provide health care coverage to up to 1 million uninsured New Yorkers. But ask any lawmaker or lobbyist who made this plan happen, and fingers point immediately to a behind-the-scenes player who is not even a state official: Dennis Rivera, president of 1199, New York State's largest health care union.

headline.main: Getting Tobacco to Fund Health Care for Have-Nots

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks to projections of a large and growing federal budget surplus, the presidential candidates are proposing ambitious initiatives that reveal clear differences within and between the parties over taxes, spending programs and Social Security's long-term problems. For the first time in decades, the candidates this time around are not constrained by the need to deal with big budget deficits. Indeed, it is very likely that the current forecast of a $3 trillion surplus over the next decade -- of which $2 trillion would come from excess Social Security revenues -- will be revised upward in the next several months, putting even more money on the table.

headline.main: CANDIDATES OFFER VARIETY OF WAYS TO SPEND SURPLUS

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent debates between Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley have put health care squarely on the campaign agenda, but no doubt confused many voters about complex cost and coverage issues. Mr. Bradley proposes an expensive plan that invites uninsured people to buy coverage, with the help of federal subsidies for families with incomes of up to about $50,000, from any one of hundreds of private plans that serve federal employees. Mr. Gore, arguing that Mr. Bradley's plan would lead to unacceptably high tax increases or federal spending cuts, proposes taking modest steps that would reduce the number of uninsured people by expanding existing federal-state programs to cover more low-income children and their parents. He would also offer tax credits to individuals and small businesses that acquire coverage. The difference between the two approaches poses the central question that divides liberals from moderates in the Democratic Party: Is universal access to health insurance worth its costs?

docs.lead_paragraph: In his professorial style, former Senator Bill Bradley reminds some people of Adlai E. Stevenson. Others hear the liberal idealism of Robert F. Kennedy in his speeches, or find his distaste for hardball politics reminiscent of Michael S. Dukakis. But the candidate that Mr. Bradley invokes most often in his insurgent campaign for president is not a liberal or even a Democrat. It is former President Ronald Reagan, in whose political playbook Mr. Bradley and his advisers have found much to admire, and perhaps emulate, as they battle Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic nomination.

headline.main: Seeking Upset, Bradley Enlists Unlikely Model

docs.abstract: Article in series, The State of the Races, on 2000 Presidential campaign focuses on campaign of former Democratic Sen Bill Bradley; is invoking former Pres Ronald Reagan in insurgent campaign, finding much to admire in Reagan's political playbook; is projecting sunny optimism, is focusing on few issues and is running as celebrity outsider, trying to build anti-Washington rebellion against White House scarred by scandal; game plan has helped him mount surprisingly potent challenge to Vice Pres Al Gore in which he has emerged from virtual obscurity in just 15 months to match Gore in fund-raising, pulled even with him in polls in New Hampshire and has built national organization that has given him long shot at scoring upset; photo (M)
